item.title: Introduction
item.description:
What Are Differential Equations Anyway?

This lecture introduces the subject with Newton’s Law of Cooling

$$ \frac{\mathrm{d} u}{\mathrm{~d} t}=-K\left(u(t)-T_{0}\right), $$

where $u=u(t)$ denotes the temperature of an object at time $t$ in an environment with constant ambient temperature $T_0$. Many notions that will appear in the course are introduced. Examples are integral curves, initial-value problems, equilibrium states, and phase line analysis.

Full Set of Lecture Notes

The notes for this lecture are available here.

Supplementary Jupyter Notebook

item.title: The Initial-Value Problem and the Definite Integral
item.description:
Summary

Notion of an initial-value problem is introduced. Integral representation of solutions of an initial-value problem for differential equations of the form

$$ \frac{\mathrm{d} u}{\mathrm{d}t} = f(t) $$

is explained.

Full Set of Lecture Notes

The notes for this lecture are available here.

item.title: Separable Equations
item.description:
Summary

We cover solving separable differential equations which are of the form

$$ \frac{\mathrm{d} x}{\mathrm{~d} t}=h(t) g(x). $$

Full Set of Lecture Notes

The notes for this lecture are available here.

Supplementary Jupyter Notebook

item.title: First-Order Linear ODEs
item.description:
Summary

This lecture evolves around the fact that if a solution for the first-order linear ODE

$$ \frac{\mathrm{d} x}{\mathrm{d} t}+p(t) x=f(t) $$

exists, we can always find it. General solution, particular solutions, and using integrating factors are covered.

Full Set of Lecture Notes

The notes for this lecture are available here.

Supplementary Jupyter Notebook

item.title: First-Order Linear ODEs with Constant Coefficients
item.description:
Summary

We study how to solve differential equations of the form

$$ \frac{\mathrm{d} x}{\mathrm{~d} t}+k x=f(t). $$

A special case of the Method of Undetermined Coefficients is also introduced.

Full Set of Lecture Notes

The notes for this lecture are available here.

item.title: Growth and Decay Problems
item.description:
Summary

We cover differential equations that model certain types of growth and decay. Examples include population growth equation, logistic equation, etc.

Full Set of Lecture Notes

The notes for this lecture are available here.

Supplementary Jupyter Notebook

item.title: Second-Order Linear Differential Equations
item.description:
Summary

We cover finding general solution of second-order linear differential equations which are of the form

$$ \frac{\mathrm{d}^{2} x}{\mathrm{~d} t^{2}}+p(t) \frac{\mathrm{d} x}{\mathrm{~d} t}+q(t) x=f(t). $$

The notion of linear independence is also introduced.

Full Set of Lecture Notes

The notes for this lecture are available here.

item.title: Initial-Value Problems for Homogeneous Equations
item.description:
Summary

We continue our study of second-order linear differential equations

$$ \frac{\mathrm{d}^{2} x}{\mathrm{~d} t^{2}}+p(t) \frac{\mathrm{d} x}{\mathrm{~d} t}+q(t) x=f(t). $$

Full Set of Lecture Notes

The notes for this lecture are available here.

item.title: Reduction of Order
item.description:
Summary

Suppose we are lucky enough to know a solution $x_{1}(t)$ of the second-order linear homogeneous ODE

$$ x^{\prime \prime}+p(t) x^{\prime}+q(t) x=0 . $$

Then we can find another solution of this ODE by solving a first-order differential equation.

Full Set of Lecture Notes

The notes for this lecture are available here.

item.title: Second-Order Homogeneous Linear Constant-Coefficient ODEs
item.description:
Summary

We consider the general linear, second-order homogeneous and constant-coefficient differential equation

$$ a x^{\prime \prime}+b x^{\prime}+c x=0, $$

where the coefficients $a, b$, and $c$ are real constants and $a \neq 0$.

Full Set of Lecture Notes

The notes for this lecture are available here.

item.title: Mechanical Vibrations I: Free Response
item.description:
Summary

This lecture starts the treatment of a horizontal mass-spring system with mass $m>0$ and spring constant $k>0$:

$$ m \frac{\mathrm{d}^{2} x}{\mathrm{~d} t^{2}}+\delta \frac{\mathrm{d} x}{\mathrm{~d} t}+k x=f(t), $$

where the damping parameter $\delta\geq 0$ may or may not be zero. We start with the free response: $f(t)\equiv 0$.

Full Set of Lecture Notes

The notes for this lecture are available here.

item.title: Method of Undetermined Coefficients
item.description:
Summary

The Method of Undetermined Coefficients provides a way to obtain a particular solution of a linear second-order constant-coefficient non-homogeneous ODE

$$ a x^{\prime \prime}(t)+b x^{\prime}(t)+c x(t)=f(t) $$

in case the forcing $f(t)$ is comes from a number of special types of functions — one reduces the problem to a system of linear algebraic equations.

Full Set of Lecture Notes

The notes for this lecture are available here.

Supplementary Jupyter Notebooks

item.title: Mechanical Vibrations II: Forced Response
item.description:
Summary

We continue with the solution of ODEs that govern a spring-mass system:

$$ m x^{\prime \prime}(t)+\delta x^{\prime}(t)+k x(t)=f(t), $$

where $\delta \geqslant 0$ is the damping constant, $m>0$ is the mass of the object, and $k>0$ is the spring constant. $f(t)$ is forcing (or input).

Full Set of Lecture Notes

The notes for this lecture are available here.

Supplementary Jupyter Notebooks

item.title: Variation of Parameters
item.description:
Summary

Our quest on finding a particular solution of

$$ x^{\prime \prime}(t)+p(t) x^{\prime}(t)+q(t) x(t)=f(t) $$

continues. Earlier, we used the Method of Undetermined Coefficients to do that. That method had two restrictions

  • the coefficients $p(t)$ and $q(t)$ had to be constants (the ODE is constant-coefficient),
  • the forcing $f(t)$ had to be from special families of functions such as exponentials, trigonometric, polynomials.

With the Variation of Parameters, we will lift these restrictions.

Full Set of Lecture Notes

The notes for this lecture are available here.

item.title: Laplace Transform
item.description:
Summary

We introduce the Laplace transform

$$ F(s)=\mathcal{L}[f(t)]=\int_{0}^{\infty} \mathrm{e}^{-s t} f(t) \mathrm{d} t $$

of a function $f(t)$ defined for $t\geq 0$. We cover the existence theory and properties of this transform.

Full Set of Lecture Notes

The notes for this lecture are available here.

item.title: Inverse Laplace Transform
item.description:
Summary

We cover the inverse of the Laplace transform.

Full Set of Lecture Notes

The notes for this lecture are available here.

item.title: Solving an Initial-Value Problem Using Laplace Transform
item.description:
Summary

We now use Laplace transforms to solve initial-value problems. To do this, we cover how differentiation corresponds to multiplication under the Laplace transform.

Full Set of Lecture Notes

The notes for this lecture are available here.

item.title: The Convolution Theorem
item.description:
Summary

For given $F(s)$ and $G(s)$, we cover how to compute the inverse Laplace transform $ \mathcal{L}^{-1}[F(s) G(s)]. $

Full Set of Lecture Notes

The notes for this lecture are available here.

item.title: Systems of Linear Differential Equations
item.description:
Summary

We cover systems of linear differential equations, introduce the matrix formulation, and cover the relevant matrix theory.

Full Set of Lecture Notes

The notes for this lecture are available here.

Supplementary Jupyter Notebook

There are multiple Jupyter notebooks embedded below.

Matrix Theory

Systems of ODEs

item.title: Phase Plane Analysis
item.description:
Summary

We continue analyzing solution trajectories for linear systems of first order homogeneous differential equations with constant coefficients:

$$ \begin{aligned} &\frac{\mathrm{d} x}{\mathrm{~d} t}=a x+b y \\\ &\frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{~d} t}=c x+d y \end{aligned} $$

We cover

  • Phase portraits,
  • Equilibrium points and their classification,
  • Direction fields.

Full Set of Lecture Notes

The notes for this lecture are available here.

Supplementary Jupyter Notebook

There are multiple Jupyter notebooks embedded below.

Introduction

Systems with two real distinct eigenvalues

Systems with a pair of complex-conjugate eigenvalues

item.title: Qualitative Analysis of First-Order ODEs
item.description:
Summary

We end the semester with qualitative analysis of first order ODEs that are autonomous:

$$\frac{\mathrm{d} x}{\mathrm{~d} t}=f(x).$$

Full Set of Lecture Notes

The notes for this lecture are available here.

item.title: Existence & Uniqueness
item.description:
Summary

In this appendix we cover existence and uniqueness theory for initial-value problems of the form

$$ \left\{ \begin{aligned} \frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{d} t}&=f(y,t)\quad t>0 \\\ y(t_0)&=y_0 \end{aligned} \right. $$

Jupyter Notebook

item.title: Some Modeling
item.description:
Summary

In this appendix we cover modeling certain physical/chemical phenomena by first-order linear ordinary differential equations.

Jupyter Notebook
